reviewText: The Season 6 writers for True Blood must think the fans are very stupid; otherwise why would this season be approved to see the light of day? It is extremely hard to believe that the captivating Seasons 1-4 belong to the same tv series/franchise as Season 6. So Bill Comptom (aka Billith) is now a superhuman mini-god and vampire savior who can walk in the daylight and although he professes to despise Sookie, but then he quickly allows Warlow (a sexy-macho vampire/faeri hybrid?????) to save her from an untimely death at the hands of her father? And stupid sex-starved Sookie is even more stupider, if such a term/phrase exists in the English language. Meanwhile, Sam Merlott the shifter is still running around half-naked as usual and having sex with the first random female that crosses his path? Lafayette is still seeing ghosts, visions, and apparitions in his drug-warped mind. Tara is still over-acting her scenes and is even more annoying than usual. And incredibly, Alcide suddenly mans up in a story line that left me feeling completely cheated out of the $34.99 I spent buying this truly ridiculous season!

reviewText: True Blood Season 6 streets June 3rd, 2014.*Five commentaries with cast and crew including executive producer Brian Buckner, Stephen Moyer, Carrie Preston, Amelia Rose Blaire and more.*Inside the Episodes Featurettes: Learn about the backstories of each episode with revealing interviews from the show writers with ten behind-the-scenes featurettes.*Vamp Camp Files: Get an inside look at the secret trove of documents detailing the effort to eradicate vampires via the institution known as "Vamp Camp."*True Blood Lines: Uncover secrets from character relationships past and present in this engaging fully interactive season guide and information archive.*Episode Previews & RecapsCreator (of the show, not the books in which they're based on) and showrunner Alan Ball left True Blood (to helm Cinemax's Banshee, great show) after the fifth season and this worried a lot of fans. While I can say that this show has changed a lot from season 1 to season 6, it has been a natural progression and one that I don't feel was too forced. That being said, I didn't find season 6 as engaging or enthralling as the previous 5 seasons, which is sad because this season puts all of the main characters in the most danger yet. The show is still filled with gore, tons of nudity and some really cool action scenes and one liners that this show has become so popular for. Yet I found myself not being as emotionally invested in these characters as I normally am.Season 6 brings back Anna Camp (Pitch Perfect) as Steve Newlin's estranged wife Sarah, and we have some new characters like Ben Flynn played by Robert Kazinsky (Pacific Rim) and  Nicole Wright played by the beautiful Jurnee Smollett-Bell (Friday Night Lights). But for me I thought Arliss Howard (Wilder Napalm) as Truman Burrell and Rutger Hauer (Bladerunner) as fairy king Niall Brigant were the stand out new additions to the show. As per usual, this is a character driven series but this season all bets are off for who lives and who dies. With tainted True Blood about to hit shelves, most of the main vampires locked up by Governor Burell, Sookie is after Warlow before he gets her, Jason is as confused as ever, and Bill has no idea who he is or what powers he has, or for how long he'll have them.While some characters are dramatically down played from previous seasons (I feel like Sookie and Alcide had the least amount of screen time this season, until the last two episodes) we see a lot of Eric and Pam and Jessica and these new characters which helped make this season feel a bit more fresh, and at the same time a bit distant and stale when compared to previous seasons. Ultimately I think anyone who is a True Blood fan will enjoy season 6, it has some big moments, fills in some blanks from previous season loose ends, and delivers a lot of the things we've come to love from this show. Granted this is probably the weakest season since season 2, I still enjoyed it as much as I ever do. There were some very cool throw-away scenes in the last two episodes that were very reminiscent of season 1 and had a very light hearted feeling to it. And the last 2 episodes were the best of the season. Of course it ends with a cliff hanger to segue nicely into season 7. True Blood isn't for everyone, but for anyone who has been watching this show for the last 5 seasons, you'll be in for some great treats in season 6.

reviewText: I am not going to critique the story line, only the video and audio quality which are outstanding.............and that is sort of a problem.The Blu-ray version of this is so highly defined you can see all the bumps/scars/wrinkles on people's faces along with the large amounts of makeup used in an attempt to keep (mostly) the actresses looking young. HBO might want to use a glamour filter (ha)  in the future when rendering high-def material. It sort of takes the fantasy away to a slight degree, to see that they are actually human.My player/receiver plays this in DTS mode (I have it set to pick the format) and it is amazingly "big" and "crisp". The opening credit music comes from everywhere.When "Bill" was making the mini earthquakes the subwoofer was dancing around the floor.You won't be disappointed in the quality of either the video or audio.

reviewText: One of the most appealing things about the first few seasons of TRUE BLOOD was not just how addictive it was, or how appealing the characters were, but is that the first few seasons seemed to have focus. There weren't twelve different storylines that were trying to eclipse each other; they all seemed to come together in the end. But starting really with Season Four, it started to run a little off the rails, but that was excusable to an extent because the show still worked well. But in Season Five, it started to really wander all over the place and all the character work that had come before became an afterthought in attempts to propel the weirdness of the goings-on in Bon Temps into the stratosphere, combining seven or eight different plots that seemed to go almost nowhere, and once it got to the finale, nothing really coalesced.Season Six is almost a perfect distillation of the bad parts of this show and how bad it can get.So Bill's a god after drinking the blood of Lilith; Sookie learns who sold her out to Warlow, the vampire that is coming to make her his bride for all of eternity; Sam gets involved with ANOTHER moronic subplot that is so perfunctory that it's hard to believe that it took the writers more than ten minutes to put it together; Tara is still lame; Eric and Pam are still cool; Jessica is still sexy but scared; Jason is still trying to be the hero; Lafayette is still rocking the mystical mojo; humans are still trying new things to kill all the vampires. It's pretty much the status quo.However, the worst treated characters in the series are the Bellefleurs, and I don't just mean that in terms of plot. There are so many unnecessary moments of suffering for that family that just don't make sense, and the loss of who is my favorite character of the show was just so poorly executed that it just baffles me. I don't want to include who it is because I'd like to keep this spoiler-free.Then there's the stupidity of the Sam/Alcide feud. WHY IS THIS NECESSARY? Is it just more chest-thumping to prove how alpha-male these guys can get? Because it certainly doesn't do anything for their characters.And then there's the very worst thing: the reduction of Sookie, a strong, independent woman to nothing more than a self-admitted "danger whore". The show so blatantly exploits her Anna Paquin for her faux-innocent sexiness so that they can extract at least one nude sex scene for this season, despite how debasing it is to her character, because this show apparently NEEDS Sookie having sex. It's an insult to fans of this show, and more than anything, it's an insult to Sookie.Not too long after the finale of this season, HBO announced that the upcoming season would be its last. As far as a quality scale, this show should have been cancelled two years ago, but at least it's finally coming.And it really can't come too soon.
summary: Oh, man, am I glad this show is ending next season.

reviewText: We just finished watching the Season 6 True Blood disks.  They were good but in a different style than many of the previous seasons.  Since the TV version has deviated so much from the Sookie Stackhouse books they are writing their own script and story as they move along.  The program is shown on a pay for view network and they have included a lot of sex, nudity and graphic bloody violence to boost the ratings.  We rated the season as a 4 star as my wife enjoys the shows more when Sookie has a strong love interest and a little less violence with everyone having sex with everyone else.  The plot line is starting to get weak.  We have read all of the books and seen all of the TV series.I won't ruin the storyline with any spoilers but the plot does have a lot of action and it is pretty good at times and at others the producers just expected the violence and sex to carry the story.  The plot line is getting a little stale and this season is not as good as some of the previous seasons.  It is still worth watching and it is entertaining and that is why we rated it a 4 star DVD set.This season was a bit short and when we finished the last episode we both looked at each other and said, "That's it?"  The last couple of episodes saved the season for us.  Just when it was getting really good it ended.
summary: A solid continuation of the series but the plot line is getting weak!

reviewText: I think the core characters are still my favorite part of this series and it still remains a great metaphor for discrimination across gender race culture etc. I think Alan Ball is brilliant and he brought on a great group of writers but I do think True Blood needs to finish in the next series, it makes sense and all good things need to come to an end.I do wish that the relationship with Pam and Tara had not been so vaguely treated or dismissed in this series, that seemed a little like they just didn't want to do the work to develop this, that said all else was fun I still enjoyed every episode and not being a vampire or zomby fan ever -True Blood really did turn that concept on its head.I look forward to the final series.
summary: Moving on out but still great fun

reviewText: To be fair, I'm not sure if the SERIES has truly lost its appeal for me, or if the horrific debacle of the last book was the final nail in the coffin. In either case, I'm done. My long relationship with this series (both books and show) ended with a whimper rather than a bang. The end started off simply enough. One night I didn't make sure to sit down and watch an episode. It took me more than a week to watch it On Demand, and I couldn't see the subsequent episode before I had finished the previous one, now could I? It just became easier and easier to put off watching the show and finally I just asked myself why I was bothering. Obviously, I wasn't invested in the show anymore. I cannot point to one, single factor which caused the rift. I can, however, say with some certainty that I no longer felt connected to the characters and I felt as if they were becoming strangers that I didn't particularly like and in whose fate I wasn't particularly interested in anyway. Thus began the weaning process. It was painless, rather like a completely amicable divorce. Bloodless, lacking passion or anger. I was simply done. This show is like an ex-lover. At one time, we had significant heat and chemistry. Then we simply drifted apart and now there is nothing between us but a nostalgic fondness for the good old days. I wish you well, True Blood, but I won't be there to see it.
summary: For the first time, I didn't finish watching the season

reviewText: (Warning: spoilers ahead)In years to come-True Blood fans may look back on the scene from episode 9 where all the vampires are dancing and holding hands like a bunch of idiot as the PRECISE moment when True Blood jumped the shark.  Now I'm not saying season 6 is all bad or even terrible.  It's still True Blood so it's still entertaining.  In some ways, I even thought it was an improvement over the disappointing season 5.  The problem however seems to be two-fold:1) This season lacked the feel of a "real" True Blood season.  It almost felt like a "side season" or something not quite a part of the actual series but still related (sort of like Battlestar Gallactica one-offs like "The Plan" and "Blood and Chrome").  It just felt sort of empty and insignificant with no big threat or real enemy to fight.  The big-bad this season looked like it was going to be Warlow.  In the end however Warlow just came across as a chump, died like a chump and never really added much of anything to the story arch except for giving Sookie something and some ONE to do.  The governor-another possible central threat likewise seemed unimportant and added nothing to the bigger picture.  And what about Billith?  Sookie was right on the nose when she said, "you're not a god Bill, you're just an a** hole."  So really, out of three possible threats-there wasn't really much of any threat or any kind of real substance to keep the viewer interested.2) This season was all over the place and I mean REALLY all over the place.  Many of the characters we know and love seemed to do completely irrational things or they just became more and more unlikeable as the season went on.  Eric was particularly nasty in the beginning, Bill was pretty much a dirt bag throughout even when he wasn't being Billith and even Alcide-who seems like one of the most morally grounded characters on the show became more and more unlikeable by the time the season ended.  Also-the story seemed to change on a whim without any true direction as to where they were taking it.  For those of you who watched this season-look back and try to describe it.  You can pretty sum it all up in a sentence or two.  "So yeah, the government decides to capture vampires to study and torture them then there's this Warlow guy who may or may not be a bad guy that Sookie jumps all over even though she's been giving Alcide the cold shoulder for years, oh and Bill is a god-somehow that factors into things, though I don't really see how...."Don't get me wrong.  This season was still entertaining and I still enjoyed watching it, but it just feels like if they don't start to right the ship a bit, True Blood could become the next show to fizzle out creatively and make us wish for it to end.  Please, writers-get this show back on track.  I miss the quality of the first four seasons.PS: Writers- please also kill off Bill.  Pretty pretty please.  His character has run its course, and he's been a  d**che bag for about three or four seasons now.
summary: The bloom is off the rose

reviewText: I am a huge fan of the show and I usually wait for each episode with impatience. This season though I found myself not that engaged with the story-line. Last season ended with a loud bang, with Bill gaining some scary powers and Eric, Sookie and the rest of the band running away from the compound. Here we see how the story continues and the series quickly jumps into topics that have to do with Warlow, Sookie's past and a powerful anti-vampire group.The premise of the story is not bad, but the first half of the season the execution is lacking. It almost feels as if the writers did not really know which direction to take this series in. Finally, in the second half of the season, the story picks up and the end is much better than the beginning. Overall though, it is clearly the weakest season so far and it has shown in the drop in ratings.Sadly, this was probably one of the contributing factors for HBO to decide that there will only be one more season of this show. I truly hope that the last season is better than this one and we get the ending that the series deserves. It would also be good if they go back to 12 episodes, since 10 feels a little short. When things started to get good, the season ended.

reviewText: Loved the books...and unfortunately books don't often translate well to film...er...dvd.  This season is out into its own territory, but is related to season 5, which is related to season 4, which is...  Season 6 is great, don't get me wrong, but we are not really following the books anymore to a great extent. I'll let others give you a scene by scene breakdown.  I read all the Sookie Stackhouse books first, then started watching True Blood.  I'm enjoying the series tremendously...and finally getting to see who these people (?) are!  If you enjoyed the books you'll like the series.  If you haven't read the books, you'll enjoy the series!  Now go buy the books!

reviewText: TRUE BLOOD has been my favorite show on TV since its inception. Each year, Alan Ball envisioned another one of Charlaine Harris's books, with excellent results. Season 5 however stopped following the books. Instead, last year initiated characters and plot lines, which season 6 resolves. First of all there's Warlow, a powerful, malicious vampire who killed Sookie's parents, and has a claim on her life. The last episode of season 5 created the character of "Billith", an amalgamation of the vampire goddess Lilith, and Bill retooled as a religious fundamentalist. Along with Warlow, the other primary antagonist for this season is the vampire hating governor of Louisiana, Truman Burrell. This season introduced some new characters. Fans of the books, will be pleased to learn that the fairy prince Niall, perfectly portrayed by Rutger Hauer (Blade Runner), has escaped from a parallel dimension to aid his grandchildren Sookie and Jason, in their fight against Warlow. While walking to work, Sookie meets Ben, a handsome stranger she develops feelings for. The other storylines include the Billith-Jessica arc, as Bill tries to understand his new godlike powers, and how he is to prevent his vision of the vampire cast members from meeting the sun. Another arc is Eric-Pam-Tara-Nora, all on the run from the genocidal war that Governor Burrell is waging against all vampires. The Alcide-Sam-Emma-Nicole arc revolves around the fallout from Luna's death, Emma's fate, Alcide's role as Pack Master, and the human rights worker Nicole, who quickly replaces Luna, as Sam's new special someone. Last of all, we have the Bellefleur axis (Terry, Arlene, Sheriff Andy and his fairy daughters). Terry still feels guilty from killing his Marine Sargent last season, while Andy's four fairy hybrid daughters create situations as they grow up "overnight". Finally, lets call Governor Burrell, his girlfriend Sara Newlin, and his daughter Willa, another axis. If all that sounds like a confusing mess, it is.The basic problem with this many story arcs, and character clusters, is how to keep them linked together, however tenuously. Throughout most of the season, you have Sookie, Ben, Niall and Jason exploring the Warlow dilemma, the vampires fighting Governor Burrell in and around the vampire concentration camp, Alcide and the werewolf pack chasing after Sam, Emma and Nicole, and the Bellefleurs worrying about Terry's insanity, and Andy's half fairy daughters. At best you have cohesion during the first and last episodes. Alan Ball's departure from the show, and the trouble finding a suitable replacement, may be partly to blame for the disjointed vibe. This year was said to portray the theme that evil corrupts, embodied by Bill's megalomania caused by wielding Lilith's powers, Alcide's new role as packmaster of the werewolves, and the Governor's power over the world's vampires, and their True Blood supply. However, which year DIDN'T portray the corruption of power? (Marnie, Salome, the Newlins, etc.) My major complaint, was the lack of interaction Sookie had with most the cast, especially Sam, Eric and Tara. Others have had problems with all the strange creatures, like the vampire-god hybrids, fairy-human hybrids, vampire-fairy hybrids, shifter-human hybrids, and shifter-werewolf hybrids. (Yes, these are all in the show this year.) For a show that takes itself so seriously, its become pretty wacky. Of course, the number of episodes was limited to ten, due to Anna Paquin's pregnancy. The tenth episode set up season seven, promising vampire-zombie hybrids, and a symbiotic allegiance between vampires and the human citizens of Bon Temps. Waiting between seasons doesn't suck like it used to.  Let's just hope we don't end up waxing nostalgic for the "good ole days" of Terry's fire monster.
summary: What Ever Happened to Billith Warlow?
